discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Answer B
Install Webex Meetings VDI plugin on thin client systems
For full featured meetings with Webex App:
On Windows or MacOS thin clients, install the bundled (App + Meetings) plugin.
On Linux thin clients, install the separate Meetings VDI plugin after installing the separate App VDI plugin.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cloudCollaboration/wbxt/vdi/wbx-vdi-deployment-guide/wbx-teams-vdi-deployment_chapter_010.html#Cisco_Task_in_List_GUI.dita_6ca8c516-cd1e-45c4-a33b-766da846195f

choices.B: Install two separate VDI plugins on the VDI thin client.
choices.A: Install three separate VDI plugins on the VDI thin client.
choices.D: From Control Hub, configure VDI optimization for the Webex app.
choices.C: Configure the VDI thin client and install the Webex app.

questions.question_text: An engineer must deploy the Cisco Webex app to a Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI) environment and support full-featured meetings. Which action must the engineer take to meet these requirements?

choices.B: on a Cisco Expressway-C connector host server
choices.A: on an on-premises Microsoft Active Directory server
choices.C: on a server in the Webex Data Center

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
You can install the Cisco Directory Connector on these supported Windows Server versions:
■■ Windows Server 2019
■■ Windows Server 2016
■■ Windows Server 2012 R2
■■ Windows Server 2012
■■ Windows Server 2008 R2
■■ Windows Server 2003
To address a cookie issue, Cisco recommends that you upgrade your domain controller to a release that contains the fix, either Windows Server 2012 R2 or 2016.
CCNP Collaboration Cloud and Edge Solutions CLCEI 300-820 Official Cert Guide

An engineer troubleshoots an outbound call failure on an ISDN-PRI circuit. The engineer is suspecting the error “Incompatible Destination”. Which debugs or commands are run in the voice gateway to troubleshoot the issue?

discussion.content:
C is correct, there is no "Incompatible destination" error message in q921

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/dial-access/integrated-services-digital-networks-isdn-channel-associated-signaling-cas/8607-isdn-disc-code.html

comments.content:
so it is not useful a q921 debugs, it is to debug D-channel and debug voip ccapi inout is to debug call control API, not ISDN.
The question begin wit a suspect of the engineer and they must confirm that suspect, and the way to confirm that is debug isdn q931.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
It seems a layer 3 problem. So it is necessary to get q931 debugs and a show isdn status to get any idea of where could be the problem.

Selected Answer: C
C
Will show disconnect reason due to incompatibility

Selected Answer: C
I agree with (On3), there is no "Incompatible destination" error message in q921
On3 is right "incompatible destination" is an error a "Disconnect Cause Code" from debug isdn q931. Answer is C

comments.content: However, q921 does not make a Layer 3 problem. Also, the debug voip ccapi inout EXEC command is to trace the execution path through the call control API, so it is not so useful to trace a ISDN call

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Using the debug voip ccapi inout command you get the following Call informations in detail, like Calling Number, Called Number,

Incoming Dial-peer, Outgoing Dial-peer, Trunk group lables, ANI (A Number CLI), ANI type and also the CAUSE VALUE.

This Cause Value well help you to identify the reason for call drop

So it is A. ccapi will help to understand error

choices.A:
debug isdn q921
debug voip ccapi inout
choices.B:
debug voip ccapi inout
show controller t1
choices.C:
debug isdn q931
show isdn status

questions.question_text: An engineer must configure DTMF relay on a Cisco Unified Border Element by using RFC2833 as the preferred relay mechanism and KPML as the next preferred relay mechanism. The engineer logs in to the CUBE and enters the dial-peer configuration level. Which command should be run at the dial-peer configuration level?

discussion.content:
The correct answer is D. dtmf-relay rtp-nte sip-kpml.

In this command:

rtp-nte refers to RFC2833 (also known as RTP-NTE or RTP Named Telephone Events), which is used for out-of-band DTMF relay over RTP.
sip-kpml refers to KPML (Key Press Markup Language), which is an alternative DTMF relay mechanism used in SIP signaling.
The order of the command specifies the preferred DTMF relay mechanisms, with RFC2833 (RTP-NTE) being the first preferred method and KPML as the next preferred. Thus, this configuration aligns with the requirement to prioritize RFC2833 and then KPML.
